title: Quantity - 2
instructions: Chose the alternative that best completes the sentence.

sentence: man will die in this war.
remarks: Corr: many a. 'much' is used with uncountable nouns. 'man' is countable.
Corr: many a. After 'many' we use plural nouns. 'man' is in the singular.
C

sentence: mistakes in his work that nothing will save him from being fired.
remarks: Corr: so many. There's an 'a' missing from in front of 'lot of'.
Corr: so many. After the expression 'many a' we use singular nouns.
C

sentence: time. This is the reason why we didn't visit you.
remarks: Corr: very little. 'few' is used with countable nouns, 'time' here is uncountable.
C
Corr: very little. 'a little' means 'some', but here we need a negative word, meaning 'non enough'.

sentence: I didn't enjoy the holiday. My wife nagged at me
time saying I was drinking too much.
remarks: C
Corr: all of the. After 'all' we cannot use a noun alone, that is, without any other determiners.
Corr: all of the. After 'most' we would need 'of'.

sentence: I ordered a box of glasses on the net, too, and when they arrived,
remarks: Corr: none. If we use 'some' in an 'some of something' structure, the verb should be 'were' or 'have', referring to a plural noun.
C
Corr: none. If we use 'most' in an 'most of something' structure, the verb should be 'were' or 'have', referring to a plural noun.
C
Corr: all. After 'every' we should use a noun, it cannot stand alone. And 'all' can be used alone in cases where it is followed by a relative clause.
Corr: all. Here 'that' should refer to a noun, but there's no noun here. 'most of what' would be correct.

sentence: If you become successful, then enemies! You will have
remarks: C
Corr: plenty. Here we refer back to the noun 'enemies', which is countable and in the plural, so 'much' is incorrect because it's used only with uncountable nouns.
Corr: plenty. 'a great deal of' is used with uncountable nouns, but 'enemies' is countable.

sentence: can do this job, but it's definitely not a difficult one.
remarks: Corr: anyone. Here 'anyone' means 'it doesn't matter who'. The job is not difficult, so 'nobody' is not correct here.
Corr: anyone. 'somebody' makes no sense here.
C
